Context:
Program Name: Electromechanical Engineering Technology - Power and Control
Code: T182
Credential: Ontario College Advanced Diploma
Duration: 3 years (6 semesters)
Starting Months: January, September
Domestic Tuition: $6,115.00 *
International Tuition: $17,837.00 **
Location: Casa Loma Campus
Program Description: Gain expertise in advanced power and control systems. The program was developed in collaboration with Toronto Hydro.
Graduates of this program are able to install, maintain, operate and troubleshoot increasingly sophisticated and automated equipment.
First two years curriculum: students gain experience with both power and control systems.
(* Domestic tuition is for the 2023-2024 academic year)
(** International tuition is for the 2023-2024 academic year)

Context:
The college offers a Power Engineering Technology diploma program. In the first two years, students gain experience with power and control systems including electric motors, controls, PLCs, generators, transformers, electrical CAD, and electrical safety code. In the third year, students continue with advanced courses in electrical installations, power transmission and distribution, power quality, electrical protection and control, project management, automation systems, and control applications.

Graduating students perform technological functions related to power and control systems, energy, robotics and automation, manufacturing, processing, and computer industries. This work is primarily in support of research, technology installation, problem-solving, product development, and design at a recognized technologist level.

Students will complete two mandatory co-op semesters. The first co-op experience takes place between semesters 4 and 5, and the second co-op experience takes place between semesters 5 and 6.

Graduates will be in high demand for their cross-disciplinary skills in utilities, power generation and distribution, robotics and automation, computer industry, manufacturing industry, renewable energy industries.

The following are the required courses for the first and second semesters:

SEMESTER 1: Code Course Name EMNG 1001 Circuit Analysis EMNG 1004 Metrology MENG 1002 Engineering Drawing MENG 1087 Machining Fundamentals MENG 1088 Occupational Health and Safety GSSC 1027 Personal Finance MATH 1160 Mathematics for Engineering Technology 1 COMM 2000 Communicating Across Contexts

SEMESTER 2: Code Course Name ELCL 1047 Residential Prints and Electrical Safety Code 1 EMNG 1013 Electric Devices EMNG 1015 Motors and Controls EMNG 1020 Computers and Microprocessors EMNG 1021 CAD Electrical Circuits

Context:
The text provides information about the abilities and skills a graduate from this college's electromechanical engineering program is expected to have. Here are the key learning outcomes of the program:

1. Fabricate and build electrical, electronic and mechanical components and assemblies
2. Analyze, interpret and produce electrical, electronic and mechanical drawings and technical documents
3. Troubleshoot electromechanical circuits, equipment, processes, systems and subsystems
4. Modify, maintain and repair electrical, electronic and mechanical components, equipment and systems
5. Design mechanical components, processes and systems
6. Design and analyze industrial motor controls, data acquisition devices and systems
7. Install and troubleshoot computer hardware and programming to support the electromechanical engineering environment
8. Analyze, program, install, integrate, troubleshoot and diagnose automated systems, including robotic systems
9. Establish and maintain inventory, records and documentation systems
10. Select and purchase electromechanical equipment, components and systems
11. Specify, coordinate and apply quality-control and quality-assurance programs and procedures
12. Develop strategies for ongoing personal and professional development
13. Contribute to project management through planning, implementation and evaluation of projects
14. Design and analyze electromechanical systems using fluid mechanics principles
15. Configure installation and apply electrical cabling requirements and system grounding and bonding requirements
16. Design, commission, test and troubleshoot electrical power systems
17. Select and recommend (not clear what is being recommended)

No specific factual information such as years, numbers, emails, names or locations were extracted from the text.

Context:
Program Information:
- The program involves testing and troubleshooting electrical power systems under the supervision of a qualified person.
- Selecting and recommending power and control equipment, systems, and components to fulfill requirements.
- Applying systems analysis tools for sustainability and efficiency in managing power and control systems.

Tuition and Fees:
- Domestic tuition for first two semesters of programs starting Fall 2022: $6,115.00 (subject to change)
- International tuition for first two semesters of programs starting Fall 2023: $17,837.00 (subject to change)
- Students are responsible for purchasing CSA standard safety shoes and prescription safety glasses if needed.
- This program is approved for OSAP funding for applicants who meet eligibility criteria.

Admission Requirements:
- Applicants require an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent.
- Minimum grade 12 English (C or U) and minimum grade 11 Math (M or U) or grade 12 (C or U).
- Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English and math or consider upgrading to achieve required credits.
- International Students should visit the International Admissions page for country-specific requirements.

Application Process:
- Domestic students apply through Ontario Colleges.
- International Students application process information can be found on the How to Apply page.
